t: Habakkuk 1
The*p prophecy that Habakkuk the prophet received.
Habakkuk’s Complaint
How*pn long, Lord,*s must I call for help, but*ld you do not listen? Or*ln cry out to you, “Violence!” but*ld you do not save?
Why*ln do you make me look at injustice? Why*ld do you tolerate wrongdoing? Destruction*ln and violence are before me; there*ld is strife, and conflict abounds.
Therefore*ln the law is paralyzed, and*ld justice never prevails. The*ln wicked hem in the righteous, so*ld that justice is perverted.
The Lord’s Answer
“Look*pn at the nations and watch— and*ld be utterly amazed. For*ln I am going to do something in your days that*ld you would not believe, even*ld if you were told.
I*ln am raising up the Babylonians, that*ld ruthless and impetuous people, who*ln sweep across the whole earth to*ld seize dwellings not their own.
They*ln are a feared and dreaded people; they*ld are a law to themselves and*ld promote their own honor.
Their*ln horses are swifter than leopards, fiercer*ld than wolves at dusk. Their*ln cavalry gallops headlong; their*ld horsemen come from afar. They*ln fly like an eagle swooping to devour;
they*ld all come intent on violence. Their*ln hordes advance like a desert wind and*ld gather prisoners like sand.
They*ln mock kings and*ld scoff at rulers. They*ln laugh at all fortified cities; by*ld building earthen ramps they capture them.
Then*ln they sweep past like the wind and go on— guilty*ld people, whose own strength is their god.”
Habakkuk’s Second Complaint
Lord,*spn are you not from everlasting? My*ld God, my Holy One, you will never die. You,*ln Lord,*s have appointed them to execute judgment; you,*ld my Rock, have ordained them to punish.

Your*ln eyes are too pure to look on evil; you*ld cannot tolerate wrongdoing. Why*ln then do you tolerate the treacherous? Why*ld are you silent while the wicked swallow*ld up those more righteous than themselves?
You*ln have made people like the fish in the sea, like*ld the sea creatures that have no ruler.
The*ln wicked foe pulls all of them up with hooks, he*ld catches them in his net, he*ln gathers them up in his dragnet; and*ld so he rejoices and is glad.
Therefore*ln he sacrifices to his net and*ld burns incense to his dragnet, for*ln by his net he lives in luxury and*ld enjoys the choicest food.
Is*ln he to keep on emptying his net, destroying*ld nations without mercy?
Habakkuk 2
I*pn will stand at my watch and*ld station myself on the ramparts; I*ln will look to see what he will say to me, and*ld what answer I am to give to this complaint.
The Lord’s Answer
Then*p the Lord*s replied: “Write*pn down the revelation and*ld make it plain on tablets so*ld that a herald may run with it.
For*ln the revelation awaits an appointed time; it*ld speaks of the end and*ld will not prove false. Though*ln it linger, wait for it; it*ld will certainly come and*ld will not delay.
“See,*pn the enemy is puffed up; his*ld desires are not upright— but*ld the righteous person will live by his faithfulness—

indeed,*ln wine betrays him; he*ld is arrogant and never at rest. Because*ln he is as greedy as the grave and*ld like death is never satisfied, he*ln gathers to himself all the nations and*ld takes captive all the peoples.
“Will*p not all of them taunt him with ridicule and scorn, saying, “ ‘Woe*pn to him who piles up stolen goods and*ld makes himself wealthy by extortion! How*ld long must this go on?’
Will*ln not your creditors suddenly arise? Will*ld they not wake up and make you tremble? Then*ld you will become their prey.
Because*ln you have plundered many nations, the*ld peoples who are left will plunder you. For*ln you have shed human blood; you*ld have destroyed lands and cities and everyone in them.
“Woe*pn to him who builds his house by unjust gain, setting*ld his nest on high to*ld escape the clutches of ruin!
You*ln have plotted the ruin of many peoples, shaming*ld your own house and forfeiting your life.
The*ln stones of the wall will cry out, and*ld the beams of the woodwork will echo it.
“Woe*pn to him who builds a city with bloodshed and*ld establishes a town by injustice!
Has*ln not the Lord*s Almighty determined that*ld the people’s labor is only fuel for the fire, that*ld the nations exhaust themselves for nothing?
For*ln the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the Lord*s as*ld the waters cover the sea.
“Woe*pn to him who gives drink to his neighbors, pouring*ld it from the wineskin till they are drunk, so*ld that he can gaze on their naked bodies!

You*ln will be filled with shame instead of glory. Now*ld it is your turn! Drink and let your nakedness be exposed! The*ln cup from the Lord’s*s right hand is coming around to you, and*ld disgrace will cover your glory.

The*ln violence you have done to Lebanon will overwhelm you, and*ld your destruction of animals will terrify you. For*ln you have shed human blood; you*ld have destroyed lands and cities and everyone in them.
“Of*pn what value is an idol carved by a craftsman? Or*ld an image that teaches lies? For*ln the one who makes it trusts in his own creation; he*ld makes idols that cannot speak.
Woe*ln to him who says to wood, ‘Come to life!’ Or*ld to lifeless stone, ‘Wake up!’ Can*ln it give guidance? It*ld is covered with gold and silver; there*ld is no breath in it.”
The*pn Lord*s is in his holy temple; let*ld all the earth be silent before him.
Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Prayer
A*i prayer*i of*i Habakkuk*i the*i prophet.*i On*i shigionoth.*i
Lord,*spn I have heard of your fame; I*ld stand in awe of your deeds, Lord.*s Repeat*ln them in our day, in*ld our time make them known; in*ld wrath remember mercy.
God*pn came from Teman, the*ld Holy One from Mount Paran. His*ln glory covered the heavens and*ld his praise filled the earth.
His*ln splendor was like the sunrise; rays*ld flashed from his hand, where*ld his power was hidden.
Plague*ln went before him; pestilence*ld followed his steps.
He*ln stood, and shook the earth; he*ld looked, and made the nations tremble. The*ln ancient mountains crumbled and*ld the age-old hills collapsed— but*ld he marches on forever.
I*ln saw the tents of Cushan in distress, the*ld dwellings of Midian in anguish.
Were*pn you angry with the rivers, Lord?*s Was*ld your wrath against the streams? Did*ln you rage against the sea when*ld you rode your horses and*ld your chariots to victory?
You*ln uncovered your bow, you*ld called for many arrows. You*ln split the earth with rivers;
the*ld mountains saw you and writhed. Torrents*ln of water swept by; the*ld deep roared and*ld lifted its waves on high.
Sun*pn and moon stood still in the heavens at*ld the glint of your flying arrows, at*ld the lightning of your flashing spear.
In*ln wrath you strode through the earth and*ld in anger you threshed the nations.
You*ln came out to deliver your people, to*ld save your anointed one. You*ln crushed the leader of the land of wickedness, you*ld stripped him from head to foot.
With*ln his own spear you pierced his head when*ld his warriors stormed out to scatter us, gloating*ln as though about to devour the*ld wretched who were in hiding.
You*ln trampled the sea with your horses, churning*ld the great waters.

I*pn heard and my heart pounded, my*ld lips quivered at the sound; decay*ln crept into my bones, and*ld my legs trembled. Yet*ln I will wait patiently for the day of calamity to*ld come on the nation invading us.

Though*ln the fig tree does not bud and*ld there are no grapes on the vines, though*ln the olive crop fails and*ld the fields produce no food, though*ln there are no sheep in the pen and*ld no cattle in the stalls,
yet*ln I will rejoice in the Lord,*s I*ld will be joyful in God my Savior.
The*pn Sovereign Lord*s is my strength; he*ld makes my feet like the feet of a deer, he*ld enables me to tread on the heights. For*pn the director of music. On my stringed instruments.
